prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [NII]205
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [NII] 205um line detection experiment of unresolved sources in the z=4.7 system BR1202-0725. We ask for Band 6, compact array observations. The pointing center has been slightly shifted with respect to the QSO coordinates, in order to best cover all the galaxies in the system. The [NII] 205um line has been observed in our PdBI data, and we ask here to use ALMA to confirm the line detections in the SMG and in the LAEs, and to set deeper constraints on the line flux in the QSO. The tuning frequency of SPW0 and SPW1 is set in order to cover the whole range of [NII] 205um redshifts of this system.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY: We base our line expectations on the [NII] 205um line observations obtained by our group with the PdBI. We aim to confirm on a 5-sigma ground the faintest line detection among the 4 objects in the system, i.e., the one associated with LAE-1. In our PdBI observations we have reported a peak flux of ~3 mJy and a line width of ~50 km/s (see Fig.2 in the proposal). We therefore ask for a rms of 0.6 mJy in a 50 km/s channel.
IMAGING: We ask for the coarsest angular resolution that allows an easy deblending of the sources in BR1202-0725, i.e., ~1". Available [CII] and [NII] data of this source suggest that only the SMG would be (marginally) resolved at these scales, so we are not going to out-resolve our targets. Our simulations with simobserve suggest that array configurations C34-1, 2 or 3 are best suited for this experiment.
CORRELATOR SETUP: We ask for the largest available bandwidth (1875 MHz per spw) in order to maximize the continuum sensitivity and the redshift coverage (needed to detect all the galaxies in the system). We ask for 8 channel spectral average in order to reduce the data rate. At this resolution, we will still be able to fully characterize the profile of the narrowest line in the system (~50 km/s wide).
BANDPASS: No special bandpass accuracy is required.
CALIBRATION: This science goal requires default calibration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [OI]146
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [OI] 146um line detection experiment of unresolved sources in the z=4.7 system BR1202-0725. We ask for Band 7, compact array observations. The pointing center has been slightly shifted with respect to the QSO coordinates, in order to best cover all the galaxies in the system. The tuning frequency of SPW0 and SPW1 is set in order to cover the whole range of [OI] 146um redshifts of this system.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY: According to models, the [OI] 146um line flux ranges between 0.3 and 3 times the flux of the [CII] 158um line. We refer here to the conservative case ([OI]/[CII]~0.3), and propose to measure on a 3-sigma ground the [OI] emission in the faintest line among the 4 objects in the system, i.e., the one associated with LAE-1. In our PdBI [NII] 205um observations we have predicted a peak flux of ~1.5 mJy and a line width of ~50 km/s. We therefore ask for a rms of 0.5 mJy in a 50 km/s channel.
IMAGING: We ask for the coarsest angular resolution that allows us to clearly disentangle the emission from the various components of this system, i.e., ~1". Available [CII] and [NII] data of this source suggest that only the SMG would be (marginally) resolved at these scales, so we are not going to out-resolve our targets. Our simulations with simobserve suggest that array configurations C34-1 or 2 are best suited for this experiment.
CORRELATOR SETUP: We ask for the largest available bandwidth (1875 MHz per spw) in order to maximize the continuum sensitivity and the redshift coverage (needed to detect all the galaxies in the system). We ask for 8 channel spectral average in order to reduce the data rate. At this resolution, we will still be able to characterize the profile of the narrowest line in the system (~50 km/s wide).
BANDPASS: No special bandpass accuracy is required.
CALIBRATION: This science goal requires default calibration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [NII]122
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [NII] 122um line detection experiment of unresolved sources in the z=4.7 system BR1202-0725. We ask for Band 8, compact array observations. The pointing center has been slightly shifted with respect to the QSO coordinates, in order to best cover all the galaxies in the system. The tuning frequency of SPW0 and SPW1 is set in order to cover the whole range of [NII] 122um redshifts of this system.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY: We base our [NII] 122um line expectations on the [NII] 205um line observations. The 122-to-205 flux ratio is typically ~5 (e.g. Beirao+10), but can be as low as ~1 in very low-density environments. We therefore propose to measure at high significance (10-sigma) the faintest line detection among the 4 objects in the system, i.e., the one associated with LAE-1, in the case of intermediate 122-to-205 flux ratios. This implies a peak flux of ~20 mJy and a 1-sigma sensitivity request of 2 mJy in a 50 km/s channel. Such a high significance will allow to robustly detect the line (at ~4-sigma level) even in the extreme case of very low-density.
IMAGING: We ask for the coarsest angular resolution. Available [CII] and [NII] data of this source suggest that only the SMG would be (marginally) resolved at these scales, so we are not going to out-resolve our targets. Our simulations with simobserve suggest that array configurations C34-1 or 2 are best suited for this experiment.
CORRELATOR SETUP: We ask for the largest available bandwidth (1875 MHz per spw) in order to maximize the continuum sensitivity and the redshift coverage (needed to detect all the galaxies in the system). We ask for 16 channel spectral average in order to reduce the data rate. At this resolution, we will still be able to characterize the profile of the narrowest line in the system (~50 km/s wide).
BANDPASS: No special bandpass accuracy is required.
CALIBRATION: This science goal requires default calibration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CI]609
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [CI] 609um line detection experiment of unresolved sources in the z=4.7 system BR1202-0725. We ask for Band 3, intermediate array observations. The pointing center has been slightly shifted with respect to the QSO coordinates, in order to best cover all the galaxies in the system. The tuning frequency of SPW0 and SPW1 is set in order to cover the whole range of [CI] 609um redshifts of this system.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY: We base our [CI] 609um line expectations on the [CII] 158um line observations, assuming a fiducial [CII]-to-[CI] flux ratio of ~12 (e.g. Meijerink+06, Walter+11). We propose to measure on a 5-sigma ground the [CI] emission in the SMG (the emission of neutral component in the LAEs being likely too faint to be detected even with ALMA). We predict a peak flux of ~1 mJy and a line width of ~710 km/s. A further factor ~2 is considered to take into account that the SMG will likely be resolved over 2 resolution elements. We therefore ask for a rms of 0.1 mJy in a 710 km/s channel.
IMAGING: We ask for the coarsest angular resolution that allows an easy deblending of the sources in BR1202-0725 (~1"). Available [CII] and [NII] data of this source suggest that only the SMG would be (marginally) resolved at these scales, so we are not going to out-resolve our targets. Our simulations with simobserve suggest that array configurations C34-3, 4 or 5 are best suited for this experiment.
CORRELATOR SETUP: We ask for the largest available bandwidth (1875 MHz per spw) in order to maximize the continuum sensitivity and the redshift coverage (needed to detect all the galaxies in the system). We ask for 4 channel spectral average in order to reduce the data rate. We note that an intrinsic channel bin of <10 km/s is needed in order to properly sample the width of the narrowest line in our system (~50 km/s).
BANDPASS: No special bandpass accuracy is required.
CALIBRATION: This science goal requires default calibration.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The interacting system BR1202-0725 at z=4.7 provides an absolutely unique opportunity to study fine structure lines (FSLs) in the early universe. This system consists of a QSO, a sub-mm galaxy (SMG), and two Ly-a emitters (LAEs), all covered by one ALMA pointing. Such a diversity in galaxy properties makes BR1202-0725 an outstanding laboratory of star formation and galaxy evolution at high-z. We have recently characterized the ISM in the system through a number of studies, including ionized carbon ([CII]158um, ALMA, Carilli et al.) and nitrogen ([NII]205um, PdBI, Decarli et al.). Intriguingly, we find that the measured [CII]/[NII] ratios span more than 1 dex, unveiling diverse physical conditions of the ISM. ALMA now opens up entirely unexplored diagnostics based on FSL emission. We propose observations of the [NII]122um, [CI]609um, and [OI]146um lines (and deeper [NII]205um observations). Analyzed jointly, these data will provide unique constraints on the physical properties (e.g., density, temperature) of the star-forming medium in 4 different galactic environments only 1.2 Gyr after the Big Bang and will serve as a crucial benchmark for future ISM studies with ALMA.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Domenici Science Operations Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
